data.title: Chin Tuck
data.information:
The purpose of Chin Tuck is to reduce the risk of “text neck” by strengthening and activating the stabilizing muscles on the front of your cervical spine. The exercise also serves as a reminder to keep your head drawn back while you’re working.

Since it is important to take breaks regularly, we recommend a standing position, but the exercise can also be performed while seated. In that case, sit at the edge of the chair with your feet planted.

data.title: Elevated Neck Activation
data.information: Elevated Neck Activation actives the muscles deep in your neck in charge of stabilizing your head. If you use muscles that are meant for other tasks, they will be become overexerted and sore, mush like a sprinter forced to run a marathon.

data.title: Elevated Neck Activation with Anti-rotation
data.information: The exercise activates and strengthens your deep neck muscles. Since these muscles are in charge of stabilizing your head it’s important they are resilient. Twisting from side to side further strengthens the muscles.

data.title: Elevated Neck Activation with Anti-rotation
data.information: Elevated Neck Activation with Anti-rotation activates and improves stamina in the muscles in change of stabilizing your head. It’s important to practice activating the correct muscles, in order to prevent discomfort.

data.title: Elevated Prolonged Neck Activation
data.information: Elevated Prolonged Neck Activation activates and strengthens your deep neck muscles. Since these muscles are in charge of stabilizing your head they need to be resilient. Activating the wrong muscles increases the risk of pain.

data.title: Grounded Neck Activation
data.information: Grounded Neck Activation actives the muscles deep in your neck. These muscles are in charge of stabilizing your head, which is why it’s important to practice activating them. If you use muscles that are meant for other tasks, they will be become overexerted and sore, like a sprinter forced to run a marathon.

data.title: Head Twist
data.information: Head Twist restores flexibility in your neck. Adequate flexibility reduces the risk of discomfort.

data.title: Neck Flexion and Extension
data.information:
Neck Flexion and Extension improves flexibility in your neck. Adequate flexibility reduces the risk of discomfort.

Since it is important to take breaks regularly, we recommend a standing position, but the exercise can also be performed while seated. In that case, sit at the edge of the chair with your feet planted.

data.title: Neck Stretch
data.information:
Neck Stretch increases flexibility in your neck. Adequate flexibility reduces the risk of problems arising.

Since it is important to take breaks regularly, we recommend a standing position, but the exercise can also be performed while seated. In that case, sit at the edge of the chair with your feet planted.

data.title: Seated Ergonomics Focus Neck
data.information: Good posture activates the muscles in a way that minimizes strain on the body. The risk of pain is reduced when various muscle groups support one another.

data.title: Shoulder Rolls
data.information:
The purpose of Shoulder Roll is to improve circulation in your shoulders and supply the muscles with oxygen and nourishment. Lack of oxygen increases the risk of pain arising.

Since it is important to take breaks regularly, we recommend a standing position, but the exercise can also be performed while seated. In that case, sit at the edge of the chair with your feet planted.

data.title: Shoulder Rolls
data.information: Shoulder Rolls stimulate blood circulation, which creates an ideal environment for healing. Regularly moving your shoulders supplies the muscles with oxygen and reduces the risk of pain.

data.title: Static Neck Muscle Activation
data.information: Static Neck Muscle Activation increases stability and resilience in your neck, reducing the risk of recurring problems.
